sentence: U.S. markets dropped on Tuesday, snapping recent winning streaks with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down for the first time in nine days on trade and geopolitical jitters and as economic data lifted inflation expectations, sending bond yields spiking.
With a slate of earnings due this week from top retailers, disappointing sales from Dow component Home Depot ( HD ) had the measures in retreat from the opening bell.
On the S&P 500, all 11 sectors were in the red, with real estate, health care and utilities sliding the most.
The Nasdaq was dented by tech losses while the CBOE Volatility Index surged about 13%.

Yields on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note jumped to 3.07%, the highest level since 2011, after retail sales data met expectations in a sign of a bounce-back in consumer spending, solidifying expectations of a June rate hike and possibly two more raises this year, according to TD Economics.
Also, Morgan Stanley lifted its outlook for personal consumption expenditure after the retail sales data to 2.6% for the second quarter from 2.5%.
The PCE price index is the Fed's preferred measure of inflation, and higher interest rates often dent stock prices.
Geopolitical jitters also weighed, with optimism over U.S.-China trade talks that lifted markets on Monday waning after the U.S. ambassador to China said the countries are still far apart.
With a Chinese delegation due in the U.S. for more discussions, Lindsey Piegza at Stifel Economics said "investors are wary the world's two largest economies will be able to sort out an agreement."

And late in the session, South Korean media reported that North Korea was cancelling talks with it over U.S. military drills in the region, although the State department said they're still planning for discussions between President Trump and Kim Jong Un.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(+) INO (+5.71%) HIV vaccine sustains durable memory responses one year after start of clinical trial

(-) SWCH (-14.96%) Net income down year on year as Q1 misses Street view

(-) TSLA (-2.67%) Reportedly to shut down Model 3 production at month end for fixes
